conclusion: Analyze the refraction of light from the point light source S in the water to the water surface using Snell's Law.
Point light source S submerged in water emits monochromatic lights A and B, forming illuminated areas on the water surface.
Light A and B together form a small circular area illuminated by polychromatic light; Light B alone forms a larger circular area illuminated by monochromatic light B.
Snell's Law relates angles of incidence and refraction to refractive indices: n_1 sin θ_1 = n_2 sin θ_2.
Apply Snell's Law to light A: n_1 sin θ_{1A} = n_{air} sin θ_{2A}, assuming n_{air} ≈ 1.
Apply Snell's Law to light B: n_2 sin θ_{1B} = n_{air} sin θ_{2B}, assuming n_{air} ≈ 1.
At the boundary of the small circle, light A and B refract at the same angle θ_{2A} = θ_{2B}, leading to n_1 sin θ_{1A} = n_2 sin θ_{1B}.
Equate expressions for refraction angles: sin θ_{2B} = (n_1/n_2) sin θ_{1A}.
The sine value of the refraction angle of monochromatic light B at the boundary of the small circular area is sin θ_{2B} = (n_1/n_2) sin θ_{1A}.
